p: Fever, headache, retro-orbital pain, and other constitutional symptoms were associated with non-severe dengue. The basic pathophysiological explanation of this finding is that these non-specific symptoms of viral febrile illness are mostly found in the febrile phase of dengue, whereas severe dengue is usually manifested during the critical phase when there is increased risk of plasma leakage and shock [ 13, 31]. For this phenomenon, patients, who were admitted during the critical phase of the disease course developed severe dengue more frequently according to our finding, as also evidenced in a previous study [ 31]. Warning signs like abdominal pain and hepatomegaly were associated with severe dengue among our patients. Abdominal pain along with persistent vomiting was reported as strong predictors of severe dengue by many researchers [ 27, 28, 32â€“ 34]. Pleural effusion along with respiratory distress and ascites were the most common presentations of severe plasma leakage, consistent with a recent study conducted in Singapore [ 27]. Ascites was not only an important predictor of dengue shock syndrome [ 14, 27] but also an early predictor for admission to the intensive care unit [ 35].
